Award.AwardTitle: Sedimentary and tectonic controls on strath terrace formation in bedrock channels
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Christian Braudrick has been granted an NSF Earth Sciences postdoctoral fellowship to be implemented at the University of California Santa Cruz. This study will use laboratory river channels to explore how changes in climate and tectonic uplift rate alter the formation of bedrock river terraces. He will test the relative importance of these two hypotheses using a sinuous laboratory channel that is able to erode both laterally and vertically. A series of experiments will investigate how bedrock terrace occurrence and morphology reflects changes in sediment supply, base level fall, and whether strath terraces arise under constant boundary conditions. These experiments will also provide a robust dataset linking sediment supply, flow hydraulics, and sediment cover in meandering bedrock channels that can be used to test and develop numerical models of bedrock river erosion.

Bedrock river terraces form when channel incision decreases and lateral erosion dominates vertical erosion. They are widespread features in tectonically active areas and are often used to infer tectonic and/or climate history, but isolating the role of climate versus tectonics has proven difficult. The study will introduce an undergraduate student interested in academic research to conduct experiments and analyze how changes in sediment supply affect the amount of the bed covered by sediment. We will also incorporate a one-day field trip to the laboratory facility as part of the geomorphology class at UC Santa Cruz and provide a field trip for land managers interested in the evolution of streams in the Central California Coast, many of which are lined by bedrock terraces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Strath terraces record periods where bedrock river incision slows down and lateral erosion of bedrock banks dominates. These terraces are often used to interpret climatic and tectonic history, with periods of lateral erosion representing high sediment supply, and incision occurring during low sediment supply, but the linkages between sediment supply and lateral erosion are unquantified. In this project, I explored the mechanisms by which lateral bedrock erosion and incision occur in a moderately sinuous experimental flume. The flume was 6.5 m long and 1.2 m wide and was filled with a weak concrete. I ran two experiments (each approximately 45 hours long) with different grain sizes to explore the patterns of erosion and sediment deposition, to better understand lateral erosion in bedrock channels that leads to strath terrace formation. The width depth ratio in both experiments was 3 or less, suggesting that bars only occur because of the channel curvature. Rivers with sedimentary beds and banks typically have larger width depth ratios (generally exceeding 8-10), but the width-depth ratio of bedrock channels is often much lower, reflecting the relatively high strength of the bank material.

            In the experimental channel, I measured the sediment supply rate, the water discharge, and the sediment flux. A point gauge on a movable cart was used to measure the water surface elevation, while the topography of the bed was measured using numerous photographs (~10 per survey) processed using Agisoft Photoscan software. Velocity was measured using an Acoustic Doppler Velocimeter (ADV) and sediment transport was monitored using underwater video cameras.

            The two experiments had similar sediment supply, but different median grain sizes (4.5 and 6.3 mm, respectively), which should have caused different bar morphology. The bar morphology was relatively similar, with 79% of the bed covered with sediment in Run 1 (4.5 mm) and 73% of the bed covered in Run 2 (6.3 mm). Models of vertical incision in bedrock rivers predict that incision is a product of the volume of sediment detached per particle impact, times the particle impact rate times portion of the bed exposed (i.e., not covered by gravel). We found that for our experiments, sediment transport was limited to areas of the bed that were already covered with sediment, and that despite 21-27% of the bed being exposed, incision did not occur in the exposed bedrock areas of the flume because the impact rate was essentially zero.

            Lateral erosion was also limited with < 1 cm of erosion occurring at the upstream end of bends prior to the bars establishing. Detailed topographic maps coupled with numerous velocity measurements show that the bed topography (primarily created by bars) coupled with the velocity field act to limit sediment interaction with the banks, limiting lateral erosion in both experiments.

            Although I observed little bank erosion, the output of these experiments will provide a unique dataset of flow velocity and bar morphology in a relatively narrow bedrock channel. Future experiments will reduce the sediment supply rate to explore whether sufficient bedrock exposure may enhance bed and bank erosion.
